properties.Name: RetailMerchandisingConditionType
properties.Description:
The type of retail merchandising condition.

Ex:
- Price Reduction
- Display
- Feature
- Feature and Display
- Temporary Price Reduction (TPR)

There are 4 commonly used merchandising conditions that manufacturers generally pay retailers to execute in order to sell more product.  Most analyses look at 4 mutually exclusive merchandising conditions:  Feature without Display, Display without Feature, Feature & Display (F&D), and Temporary Price Reduction Only (TPR or TPR Only).

Feature - Retail merchandising condition executed by retailers and measured by going through newspapers and flyers.  A Feature is a printed ad vehicle distributed by the retailer usually weekly, via newspapers, direct mail or in-store.  Most commonly used is Feature without Display.  Any Feature (with or without a Display) and Feature only (without a price cut) are also available but not used that often.

Any Promotion - Stores that have either Display, Feature, TPR or any combination of these merchandising conditions at any point during a specific period are counted in measures with "Any Promo."

Temporary Price Reduction (TPR) - Retail merchandising condition executed by retailers and measured using the retailer's POS system. A TPR is a temporary price cut of at least 5% from the regular price. If the TPR lasts for several weeks it can become the regular price.

 Display
JULY 1, 2012 By ROBIN SIMON 4 COMMENTS
In-store merchandising condition executed by retailers and measured using a sample of audited stores.  A Display is a temporary secondary location in the store different from the regular shelf location, usually an endcap or in-aisle display.  After 7 weeks, a secondary location is no longer considered temporary.  Most commonly used is Display without Feature.  Any Display (with or without a Feature) and Display only (without a price cut) are also available but not used that often.

Retail merchandising condition executed by retailers and measured by going through newspapers and flyers.  A Feature is a printed ad vehicle distributed by the retailer usually weekly,  via newspapers, direct mail or in-store.  Most commonly used is Feature without Display.  Any Feature (with or without a Display) and Feature only (without a price cut) are also available but not used that often.

Columns.Name: RetailMerchandisingConditionTypeId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a retail merchandising condition type.

Columns.Name: RetailMerchandisingConditionTypeName
Columns.Description: The name of a retail merchandising condition type.

Columns.Name: RetailMerchandisingConditionTypeDescription
Columns.Description: The description of a retail merchandising condition type.
